all.body:
Thanks for the feedback, I will take your approach to rewriting the pitch,
as well as clarifying who I am writing for. I struggle on "showing" in my
pitch writing; my show writing makes the writing longer and more awkward.

Mathieu



On Tue, Jun 11, 2013 at 8:19 AM, Amy Hoy wrote:

> Hi Mathieu!
>
> First, Jaana pointed out the important: You need to target the right
> person with this pitch.
>
> Second, the pain itself is not *exactly* my pain, but keeping the API
> docs up to date IS a pain. And even though I have that pain, I felt
> resistance in reading the rest of your (long) pitch.
>
> Overall, I think the "copywriting" in your pitch is distracting/muddying
> the *content* if that makes sense.
>
> My recommendation: Cut it back to rougher bullet points (P, D, F) and see
> how strong it seems then. Refine it there, then go back to full-copywriting
> mode.
>
> Make sense?
>
> Amy
>
>
> On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 11:53 AM, Mathieu Fenniak <
> mathieu.fenniak@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> Hi all,
>>
>> In my ongoing Safari of Web API developers, one area that keeps coming up
>> is API documentation tools. I've found a specific, compelling pain that I
>> believe I can fix, and that has a lot of potential room for future
>> development. I'd love to hear some feedback on this pitch:
>>
>> Another support ticket about the Web API hits your inbox. Every time
>> your customers hit the tiniest speedbump while using the API, they're
>> firing off terse, annoyed e-mails, and they're reaching you. It's
>> irritating; why don't they just read the documentation? It covers this
>> case. You're sure, you wrote it six months ago, and it definitely answers
>> this guy's question.
>>
>> "I tried that, but it didn't work." The documentation is out-of-date.
>> The enhancement team added a new required field to that operation about
>> four months ago, and ever since then the docs have been incorrect. You go
>> from irritated to anxious in a flash; what else snuck through without a doc
>> update?
>>
>> Imagine if you were aware when your API documentation became dated. As
>> long as you're tuned in, it's a quick job to update the docs whenever
>> they're incorrect. Customers be happy to find their answers in reliable
>> examples, tutorials, and reference material; you'd be happy that they
>> didn't have to contact you. You'd never have to explain, "Oooh, that's for
>> version 3, but I guess it doesn't work anymore." The sneaky dev team would
>> get caught red-handed when changes go into the product without doc updates.
>>
>> Welcome to the world of , the intelligent Web API
>> documentation system. You can use to test the contents of
>> your documentation against reality. Every time you update your
>> documentation, and every week (just in case), you'll get a notification
>> that your documentation was analyzed and verified against the services
>> you're writing about. Broken documentation screams at you, "Fix me!",
>> while minor compatible changes that would have no impact upon your
>> customers are ignored.
>>
>>
>> Mathieu
>>
>> --
>> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups
>> "30x500 - Alumni" group.
>> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an
>> email to 30x500-alumni+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
>> For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/groups/opt_out.
>>
>>
>>
>
>
>
> --
> Amy Hoy, amy@slash7.com
> Pirate queen, product crusader, interface radical? tagline extremist.
>
> http://www.unicornfree.com/about

all.body:
Thanks for the advice.

The article does compare Nathan's *first* *product* launch with Jarrod's
and Sasha's. Then, it goes on talking about the newer products that did
even better.

Of course, Nathan being able to pull it off the first time doesn't mean
that I can. But I can see how my product (SaaS Compass) would be more
valuable to old/large companies than new/small ones. I was thinking I could
make a mini-version by dropping off the parts than handle the full
marketing funnel and the churn.

But the comment about "artificially crippling" my product kinda hit home
too.

While price safariing, I was looking at
Starting+Sustaining.
It could have easily sold the book for $79 and had an extra package (maybe
$149, or even $199) with the spreadsheet, based on the comments given about
the pricing.

The other comparison point I found is
SaaSOptics.
Their clumsy-looking "collect SaaS data from QuickBooks, perfect
replacement for .xls" system is priced based on customer revenue and ranges
from $2,500 to $10,000 per year. To my great surprise, people are loving
this. No complaints about the price.

So, I'd be tempted to price the sheet at around $250, but I'm worried that
the small guys will not want to spend that much... yet, they could get
value from this as well. The real customer value for this one should be in
thousands, but I can't price *that* high - it varies a lot how much value a
company is going to get.

I'm pretty worried that if I offer only the higher price point, I may lose
more than half of all potential customers. Or then I just can't see this
clearly and could take patio11's advice and double the price... That'd be
$499 - which to me sounds ridiculous for a spreadsheet - no matter how cool
a tool it is.

-Jaana


On 11 June 2013 18:50, Amy Hoy wrote:

> Think about it: That was Nathan's fourth or fifth product launch.
>
> That tells you all you need to know.
>
> Amy
>
>
> On Tue, Jun 11, 2013 at 10:59 AM, Jaana Kulmala > > wrote:
>
>> Hi guys,
>>
>> I'm working on my sales page and could use your advice.
>>
>> After reading this post about Nathan Barry's pricing, I'm tempted to try
>> multiple price points:
>> http://blog.asmartbear.com/selling-ebook.html
>>
>> But... to do that, I can't just ship my creative atom. It can't be split.
>>
>> So now I'm wondering if I should add some extras to my product just to
>> justify the pricing points.
>>
>> What's your opinion on this?
>>
>> Cheers,
>> Jaana
>>
>> --

all.body:
I've got a big project on my plate (RFP approved) and green lit. It
requires native Android application development, which is a skill set we
currently do not staff in-house. We reached out to one of our previous
partners and although early negotiations went well, they decided they're
unable to take the project at this time. At this point, we're looking for *
experienced *(Mid-Senior) native Android developers with experience with
NFC technology and programming. Hardware will be provided to the end users
for use during a conference event. The event will require support through
the month of August as well.

Please let me know if this project interests any of you and we could setup
a time to chat today.

Cheers!

Ben



--
*
*
*
*

all.body:
Re: the other hosting company

I would guess that your client already knows its best to go with the person
who wrote the purchasing server. They just want to look like they have a
credible negotiating position

The other hosting company also probably know this. So they will lo-ball
you cos they don't care. Which means you need to have three answers ready

- why, technically you out do the other guys. This is the usual nice PDF
about your hosting, how it's on two different AWS locations on either
coast, how you can get hot failover up in 0.3 micro-parsecs etc.
This one is important because everyone will pretend its the reason they
take your service, so it has to be credible. Use at least two diagrams
from that Apple only diagramming tool

- why you really are cheaper even though you charge more (this is a
combination of assumptions about licenses, future outages and speed to fix,
future features that will gain them x% conversion improvements they won't
see with other hosting company. Again this is an excuse - but it needs to
be credible, so frankly the conversion rate improvements seem best bet.

- and finally, the real reason- I wrote it dumpkopfs!


But they will come back to you, soon, with "these other guys said ...".
Hit them hard and fast with the above three and your fat daily rates
before the hosting company gets mental space as the unchallenged hosting
provider (seen this from the other side a couple of times - the faster a
rebuttal gets into the heads of everyone in the decision chain the less
opposition there is. )

Don't wait to fire these back and ring up everyone you know - seriously I
have seen the internal debate turn in a few hours either way. If folks go
home Friday evening with the decision set at "the other guy is choice #1
right now, lets see what Ethan says" by Monday morning you are facing a
fixed decision to go with the others. If they go home with "the other guy
is #1 choice but Ethan has raised some very good TCO issues" then on Monday
they will meet and say "but I was thinking over the weekend that there are
some TCO issues we need to consider"

Good luck. Politics pah!




Paul Brian
07540 456 115
paul@mikadosoftware.com
@lifeisstillgood
pbrian.mikadosoftware.com

On 11 Jun 2013, at 15:19, Ethan Garofolo wrote:

@Tamer - That is a challenge. The timing of this project worked out really
well for me. I was about to start a full-time job with a company that was
really adamant about me not moonlighting as a consultant. The friend that
approached me about the job needed a web developer to do a purchasing
validation server. I wasn't able to custom build that as a consultant, but
it occurred to me that if it were a product, then it would fly as a "prior
invention." That might have been bending the spirit of the full-time job,
if not the letter. I was originally going to do it for no pay, because I'd
get a sellable product out of it. Some money came out of it though, so
that was just gravy.

@Vitaly - I'd love to hear other people's results with this approach, so if
it comes up again, please do share! When I first heard "productize your
services," I thought that meant this model. I think a few consultancies
have done this with CMSs for example. locomotivecms (a Rails CMS) was
built for this reason, I think.

@Joel - Master negotiator I am not. They basically got the right to do
anything they wanted with the deliverable. They could turn around and sell
it themselves if they wanted to. That worked for me, because their
business is art and video game development, and not running a SaaS product.
If that were, they would have just done it themselves, I figured. Plus,
they won't get updates to the code. I did retrain the right to keep
selling it on my own though. Also, when it's up and running, they'll need
someone to keep it running, and I think I have a good opportunity to land a
retainer. The current arrangement is that I just hand them working code,
but just as they don't know how to write it, they don't have the
organizational expertise to even host it just for themselves. They have a
"hosting company" that made an offer to them. I plan to make an offer
that's higher, with the competitive advantage being, "who do you want
making sure you're able to sell things in your game? A hosting company, or
the company that wrote your purchase server?" I'll word it a bit more
gracefully than that, but I would rather pay for the team that wrote it.
They'd also get updates as a result that way.

> Hey Ethan,
>
> I was wondering what sort of licensing terms you came up with for this? I

>
> Joel

> On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 8:27 PM, Ethan Garofolo wrote:
>
>> I've got a product I'm planning on launching this fall. It was born out
>> of being approached to do a contract job. The pay for that job wasn't
>> stellar, so I suggested I'd just build the thing as a product that I'd
>> license to the client. That arrangement has worked quite well, and I
>> basically got a resellable product that someone else footed a lot of the
>> bill for. It also worked nicely, because since it was originally a
>> contract job, I knew it was something that someone would at least pay
>> something for.
>>
>> I personally am waiting to have at least a few team members before
>> scaling into other products. If I do launch a product, I want to make sure
>> I'm not the only person responsible for responding to emergencies.
>>
>>
>> On Mon, Jun 10, 2013 at 5:51 PM, Vitaly Kushner wrote:
>>
>>> I know that for me its definitely X/month figure, we (all 3 partners)
>>> all have families (2 kids each) and live in a not-very-cheap neighbourhood.
>>> And while financial situation is not the same, I personally can't afford to
>>> downgrade much (especially with the planned move to Berlin).
>>>
>>> That being said I do sometimes have a free time to invest into products,
>>> so the problem is not entirely time related. We tried several times in the
>>> past, but we can't pass the 'lets get it to launch' threshold with anything
>>> product worthy. We did launch a couple of free toy projects (see
>>> http://markupslicer.com and http://isratracker.com), but nothing worth
>>> doing product out of.
>>> That, and the fact that one of the partners believes we can not sell
>>> products ourselves, that we somehow need to partner with some business guy
>>> to do it (which I don't believe).
>>>
>>> so we re-evaluated our 'getting to products' strategy again about 1-2
>>> months ago, and decided to try to scale the company by at least 50% before
>>> we get back to products, not sure if its the right strategy though.
>>>

all.body:
want to sit on it any more.

(Is there an all@ alias for hackbright? ;))

Here are my notes from the mentoring round table:

-------

About 14 people of the 20 signed up attended. (I didn't take attendance,
but felt a count might be useful.)

Useful to know day-to-day class schedule, syllabus
Awareness of other mentor skills so we can get help for mentee where we're
weak
Generally would be good to formalize mentoring/mentee expectations, close
feedback loop on performance
More structure around time spent, interaction expectations, communication
channels, possibly periodic checkins (incl daily standups)
Small commits, pushing to github often, use github infra (incl issues as
TODO/FIXME) more
Formal instruction "should" cover:
breaking things down into parts/outlining/understanding tradeoffs
debugging
Junior mentors feel unqualified to help (new students better prepared at
entry due to growing app pool)
Feeling of competition between peers (due to differing entry qualification,
progress rate, differing amounts of mentor attn, etc)
Hiring is not about liking you, it could be: company situation, skillset,
support system, finance runway/burn/timing
Tell mentees that feedback on mentors is welcome, and that mentors can be
"fired" and replaced
Rebalancing mentor/mentee through program would help (some mentors were
more and less available, some mentees wanted more help than others)
More visibility into staff roles and contact info
Companies w/ mature junior onboarding should be more visible (so that other
partners can learn from it)
Better partner company expectation setting - many partners "window
shopping" for best rather than looking to grow promising entries
Tom's crazy #1: (I didn't capture this accurately): something to do with
the program running internship itself
Tom's crazy #2: Related to partner co expectation setting, instructors
could "mock interview" at partner cos and give feedback on what would/would
not be fair assessments. Would help fit program results to hiring hopes.

Input from former students (i.e. the junior mentors) about their experience
as mentees:
* didn't know the kind of help they needed or could ask for
* a regular schedule helps, as time flies
* a channel for sharing tips/tricks/timesavers would help (I think this
could just be a student mailing list/subject protocol: subj: [tip] ... ?)
* code review a very valuable form of feedback (add mentors to github
repos)
* weekly project digest

Christian's bias to backend hurts some aspects

Moon: candidates from previous classes still looking, need cohort
support/backing

Jeremy Crazy #1:
A bunch of feedback centered around saying the program should do more of
X. Given resource constraints, I think it'd be useful to have a mechanism
for prioritizing those suggestions. I'll populate a google moderator with
tech/skills/comms to cover, to be voted on by mentors (and presumably
instructors). Final decision up to staff, of course.

Partner companies need guidance on offers/expectations. Wide variance in
per-student expectation, wide variance in company offer ($ and further
mentoring).

Jeremy crazy #2: there are a bunch of pro women-in-tech orgs. People in
those orgs work at potential hiring partners. They could be "people on the
inside". Work with them? Put another way, let's work with ada initiative
people to make internal contacts at more orgs.

all.body:
On Wednesday, June 26 from 6pm to 9pm, we will be holding the f*irst
Mentor/Mentee Mixer for the Summer 2013 class*. We have ~25 incoming
Hackbright students this summer starting June 17.

*If you can mentor again for the summer, please join us on June 26 for a
Mentor/Mentee Mixer - the first meeting!*
*
*
*RSVP here: http://hackbrightmentorship2013summer.eventbrite.com/
(invite-only)*
*
*
*If you would like to mentor this summer but absolutely cannot join us on
Wednesday, June 26 - please email me directly and let me know.*

If you have *friends* who are interested in mentoring this summer, make
sure they fill out this form first . I
am inviting the people that meet our minimum qualifications for mentoring
directly to the Eventbrite, so please don't forward the Eventbrite.

Thanks so much for all your help and mentorship! We are truly grateful for
all the support and encouragement the community have given us at
Hackbright, and appreciate any comments and feedback about how to improve
Hackbright. For example, we are starting the mentorship sooner in the
program (week 2 vs. week 3) this summer.

Cheers,
Angie


--
Angie Chang
Director of Growth
Hackbright Academy

E: a@hackbrightacademy.com
M: 562-547-4839

Want to hire more women engineers into
your tech startup or company? Hackbright
Academyis a
10-week training program designed to help women become awesome programmers.

> Overall I liked the post and I felt that it provided real value although I
> too was a bit confused about the terminology of 'outsourcer.' I wasn't sure
> if that referred to someone on the giving or receiving end of the client
> relationship.
>
> I was also a bit confused after my first skim as I remembered seeing 4
> points listed in the first section but then only reading 2 of them in
> headings. I had to go back and check to see how many points there were and
> then double check to see that if I missed them before finally seeing the
> note in the last paragraph. You might make a note under the recipe list
> that this post will only cover the first two items.
>
> I'd also think about revising the last paragraph to emphasize the next
> step for getting the next post in addition to receiving the job template.
> __________________
> Michael Prasuhn

all.subject: Re: [30x500] 1st Ebomb - How to Hire the Top 1% of Outsourcers - feedback appreciated!

all.body:
We've been busy little bees.

Regular Office Hours will resume in Julyish.

I just posted a bigass ebomb on my blog:
http://unicornfree.com/2013/how-do-you-create-a-product-people-want-to-buy

And here's the scoop for the 2-day bootcamp:

- We're covering the Sales Safari, pitch writing, and ebomb
brainstorming processes step by step with exercises and critique
- 36 seats are available to the public at $1500-1700/ea
- 4 seats will be available at $1000/ea to alumni

The exercises we're doing are all based on the exercises you've experienced
if you were in last full-length 30x500. So, while the video learning
materials are all new, the exercises will be familiar.

*Nota bene: *Unless you skipped those parts of class, or you're an alum
from way back *and *skipped the last free edition, I don't think the
bootcamp holds a lot of value for you.

Amy
--
Amy Hoy, amy@slash7.com
Pirate queen, product crusader, interface radical? tagline extremist.

http://www.unicornfree.com/about

--

all.body:
We (creativepragmatics.com) have a solid backtrack of Android projects, and certainly have senior developer skills.
We have no special NFC know-how - AFAIK there's no low-level hackery or huge frameworks involved, though.

Availability depends on how soon the project is started - we have active projects and some quotes out there from which at least 2 will almost certainly close soon. Our min. day rate currently is ?700 per day per dev.
You can also contact me offlist if you like, I'll gladly answer your questions :)

Cheers,
Manuel

Am 11.06.2013 um 20:09 schrieb Ben Lee :

> Hey All,
>
> I've got a big project on my plate (RFP approved) and green lit. It requires native Android application development, which is a skill set we currently do not staff in-house. We reached out to one of our previous partners and although early negotiations went well, they decided they're unable to take the project at this time. At this point, we're looking for experienced (Mid-Senior) native Android developers with experience with NFC technology and programming. Hardware will be provided to the end users for use during a conference event. The event will require support through the month of August as well.
>
> Please let me know if this project interests any of you and we could setup a time to chat today.
>
> Cheers!
>
> Ben
>
>
>
>
> --
>
>
> Ben Lee, Managing Partner
> www.neonroots.com | ben@neonroots.com
